etymologies: mid 19th century; earliest use found in Philip Schaff (1819–1893), theologian and historian. From German Panlogismus from pan- + ancient Greek λόγος speech, word, reason + German -ismus

definitions: The doctrine that only the rational, as apprehended by reason, is truly real.

notes.text: Often used in the context of dissent from this view, which is associated mainly with Hegel.
